title: Vo-Ve: An Explainable Voice-Vector for Speaker Identity Evaluation
author: Jaejun Lee (Music and Audio Research Group, Seoul National University), Kyogu Lee (Department of Intelligence and Information, Seoul National University), ...
relevance_why: The paper addresses speaker identity evaluation and interpretability of embedding techniques, which are critical in audio processing tasks including speech synthesis and voice conversion. Vo-Ve's explainability could enhance Haohe's research in audio generation and manipulation.
background: The work focuses on creating a novel explainable embedding system that captures speaker identity attributes to enhance evaluation methods in speech tasks.
contribution: This paper introduces Vo-Ve, a voice-vector embedding that provides explainability in speaker identity evaluation, achieving competitive performance in similarity assessments.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Conventional speaker embeddings lack interpretability, providing only similarity values without insights on voice attributes.
technical_comparison.novelty: Vo-Ve offers explicit probabilities for voice attributes, allowing for understanding of what contributes to similarity or dissimilarity between speakers.

key_innovation: Vo-Ve uniquely integrates interpretable voice attribute dimensions into speaker embeddings, moving beyond traditional approaches that operate in a less explainable manner.
real_world_impact: Vo-Ve could facilitate advancements in speaker verification, voice conversion, and text-to-speech synthesis by providing deeper insights into speaker identity, potentially improving user experience in these applications.
limitations: The study acknowledges a limited dimensionality in Vo-Ve, which may impact its expressiveness compared to conventional embeddings.

new_terms.voice-vector: **Voice-vector** refers to an embedding representation capturing voice identity attributes and their respective probabilities, providing insights into a speaker's characteristics.
new_terms.multi-label classification: **Multi-label classification** is a type of machine learning task in which each instance may be associated with multiple labels, as opposed to a single target label.

open_sourcing: The implementation code for Vo-Ve is available at https://github.com/jaejunL/vove.
